column1: Battlemind Link	Battlemind Link	divination [mind-affecting]	inquisitor 4
column3:
S personal and close (25 ft. + 5 ft./2 levels) you and 1 ally 1 minute/level Will negates (harmless) yes (harmless) Normal Use

You fuse your thoughts with an ally's
column4: allowing the two of you to fight in tandem
column5:
perfectly coordinated. You and the ally each roll initiative in combat and use the higher die result before adding modifiers. This has three effects.

Melee: If you both make melee attacks against the same creature
column6:
you both make attack rolls and both use the higher of the two dice for your attack rolls (plus bonuses).

Ranged: If you both make ranged attacks against the same creature
column7:
you both make attack rolls and both use the higher of the two dice for your attack roll (plus bonuses).

Spell: If you both cast spells and target the same area or same creature
column8:
affected creatures take a -2 penalty on their saving throw against the spells.

You and the target lose these benefits if you cannot see each other or if you or the target is unconscious or helpless.

You blast your enemies with blinding rays of sunlight. You may fire one ray

column13: but all rays must be aimed at targets within 30 feet of each other and fired simultaneously.

You mark the target with a black marking on its skin; the mark's exact appearance determined by you

column7: and when the mark is activated

column1: Blink	Blink	transmutation	bard 3
column3:
S personal you 1 round/level (D) none none "Normal Use

You ""blink"" quickly back and forth between the Material Plane and the Ethereal Plane and look as though you're winking in and out of reality at random. Blink has several effects
column4:
as follows.

Physical attacks against you have a 50% miss chance
column5: and the Blind-Fight feat doesn't help opponents
column6: since you're ethereal and not merely invisible. If the attack is capable of striking ethereal creatures
column7:
the miss chance is only 20% (for concealment).

If the attacker can see invisible creatures
column8: the miss chance is also only 20%. (For an attacker who can both see and strike ethereal creatures
column9: there is no miss chance.) Likewise
column10: your own attacks have a 20% miss chance
column11:
since you sometimes go ethereal just as you are about to strike.

Any individually targeted spell has a 50% chance to fail against you while you're blinking unless your attacker can target invisible
column12: ethereal creatures. Your own spells have a 20% chance to activate just as you go ethereal
column13:
in which case they typically do not affect the Material Plane (but they might affect targets on the Ethereal Plane).

While blinking
column14: you take only half damage from area attacks (but full damage from those that extend onto the Ethereal Plane). Although you are only partially visible
column15:
you are not considered invisible and targets retain their Dexterity bonus to AC against your attacks. You do receive a +2 bonus on attack rolls made against enemies that cannot see invisible creatures.

You take only half damage from falling
column16:
since you fall only while you are material.

While blinking
column17: you can step through (but not see through) solid objects. For each 5 feet of solid material you walk through
column18: there is a 50% chance that you become material. If this occurs
column19:
you are shunted off to the nearest open space and take 1d6 points of damage per 5 feet so traveled.

Since you spend about half your time on the Ethereal Plane
column20:
you can see and even attack ethereal creatures. You interact with ethereal creatures roughly the same way you interact with material ones.

An ethereal creature is invisible
column22: and capable of moving in any direction
column23: even up or down. As an incorporeal creature
column24: you can move through solid objects
column25:
including living creatures.

An ethereal creature can see and hear the Material Plane
column26:
but everything looks gray and insubstantial. Sight and hearing on the Material Plane are limited to 60 feet.

Force effects and abjurations affect you normally. Their effects extend onto the Ethereal Plane from the Material Plane
column27: but not vice versa. An ethereal creature can't attack material creatures
column28:
and spells you cast while ethereal affect only other ethereal things. Certain material creatures or objects have attacks or effects that work on the Ethereal Plane. Treat other ethereal creatures and objects as material.

"

This spell calls the nearest wild animal of a particular type you designate (provided the animal's CR is equal to or less than your caster level) to seek you out. The animal moves toward you under its own power
column5: so the time it takes to arrive depends on how close an animal of the desired type is when you cast the spell. If there is no animal of that type capable of reaching you within the spell's duration

column8:
and the GM may permit a Knowledge (nature) skill check (DC 15) to know what animals can be found in an area.

column10: modified by circumstances and interaction. Other than starting attitude
column11: this spell gives you no special influence or ability to communicate with the called animal
column12:
although you may use other spells or abilities to do so.

Once the spell's duration expires
column13: the animal acts in accordance with its attitude. Most animals will likely wander off
column14: but a hostile predatory animal may attack
column15:
especially if it is hungry or provoked.

Domesticated animals or animals trained by someone else
column16: including such creatures as familiars or animal companions

You can place another spell upon your person so that it comes into effect under some condition you dictate when casting contingency. The contingency spell and the companion spell are cast at the same time. The 10-minute casting time is the minimum total for both castings; if the companion spell has a casting time longer than 10 minutes
column6:
use that instead. You must pay any costs associated with the companion spell when you cast contingency.

The spell to be brought into effect by the contingency must be one that affects your person and be of a spell level no higher than one-third your caster level (rounded down
column7:
maximum 6th level).

The conditions needed to bring the spell into effect must be clear
column8: although they can be general. In all cases
column9: the contingency immediately brings into effect the companion spell
column10: the latter being ""cast"" instantaneously when the prescribed circumstances occur. If complicated or convoluted conditions are prescribed
column11: the whole spell combination (contingency and the companion magic) may fail when triggered. The companion spell occurs based solely on the stated conditions
column12:
regardless of whether you want it to.

You can use only one contingency spell at a time; if a second is cast
column13:
the first one (if still active) is dispelled.

When under the effects of this spell
column8: you can teleport up to 30 feet as a move action. You must end this movement in an unoccupied space that you can stand on within line of sight. Alternatively
column9: you can spend a move action to teleport to a standing position from lying prone. Teleporting does not provoke attacks of opportunity.
